Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2008 12:08PM gm2kieri wrote: I had my SNB at the same time as my lumpectomy.  My surgeon did not put in a drain...she said that usually they cause more problems than they solve and that once they are taken out the breast fills up with fluid anyway until the thing learns how to drain itself again.  I had mine drained several times because the fluid would build up so much.  I never felt a thing when my surgeon drained my breast....I asked her why and she said it's because the scar is numb.  Anyway, I have a little more fluid buildup (my surgery was April 17th so I does take a while to get back to normal) but I'm going to just let it reabsorb this time because it's not much.  I think it's much better to not have drains put in...but that was just my experience.  I will be having more surgery after my chemo treatments so I don't know what will happen then.
Posts.Title: Drain with SNB? MinAZ emath

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2008 11:58AM gm2kieri wrote: I have to get blood drawn and my chemo injected every week through my port.  My doctor gave me a prescription for Lidocaine and Prilocaine cream and I put it on a couple of hours before my blood draw...then the nurse just leaves the needle in there until the next morning for my chemo treatment.  If you just cover the area with the cream and then cover the whole thing with Glad Press'n Seal it works wonders!  The first time they stuck a needle in my port it really hurt but since I have had this cream I haven't felt a thing!!
Posts.Title: SNB Dye Injection jmfl Jule

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 11:55AM gm2kieri wrote: I started my chemo (DD A/C every two weeks) and will be having my third treatment this Wednesday.  After that I will have Taxol once a week for 12 weeks.  I had a lumpectomy on April 17th and did not have a clear "superior" margin so I will be having another surgery between chemo and radiation.  My biggest worry right now is that I have a very hard lump in the breast that had the surgery right below one section of my incision scar so I will be calling my surgeon in the morning to get her to take a look.  Has anyone else had this?  I'm hoping it's just scar tissue but it does worry me some.  I am 57 and got my diagnosis on April Fool's Day...some joke huh?  Anyway, the chemo is going fine...no nausea or vomiting.  I get a Neulasta shot the day after each chemo treatment and so far that has just caused minor bone aches.  The only real side effect that I notice is that I get tired pretty easily.  But I am still working (just not full time) and I actually played nine holes of golf on Friday.  So I guess everything is going well but this has sure been a shock to me.  Nobody in my family has ever had any kind of cancer (and I have a very large family!) so I don't know where this came from.  But I definitely have a positive attitude and expect to be here to see my beautiful granddaughter grow up.  Oh, and I am Stage IIB, Grade 3, and triple negative.  And I live in Maryland...anyone else from Maryland?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 03:09AM gm2kieri wrote: Hi everyone...I hope everything is going okay.  I had my third DD AC treatment on 6/11 and the Neulasta on 6/12.  Although I have not had any nausea after any of my treatments, this time it seemed to just take all my energy.  On Sunday I felt pretty crappy and seemed to feel weepy all day.  I haven't really done that much crying but Sunday I couldn't seem to hold it back.  Anyway, my fourth and final DD AC treatment will be on Wednesday, 6/25 and the Neulasta on 6/26.  Then two weeks later I will start 12 weekly Taxol treatments.  The only other real problem I have is that I don't have any vacation time at work and I can't seem to work more than 20 hours a week so  the paychecks have really sucked lately.  I'm sure the bill collectors will start calling soon!  Anyway, good luck to everyone with their next treatment.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012
